Situation1: Be patient and understanding of each other's differences.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Story: I sat across from my younger brother, who had come in for a routine check-up at my clinic. He sniffled, rubbing his nose, and I could see the familiar stubbornness in his eyes. As his brother, I wanted to be patient, to listen, to respect his feelings and not dismiss his worries, even if they seemed minor. But as his doctor, I had to focus on the symptoms, to ask clinical questions, to remain objective and not let our relationship cloud my judgment. He insisted his cold was something more serious, and I could sense his anxiety. I wanted to reassure him as a brother, to comfort him, but I also needed to maintain professional boundaries and not jump to conclusions without evidence. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something different. I could feel the tension rising inside, torn between being the understanding brother he needed and the objective doctor he expected.
